TEXT.French: Résistance
TEXT.Italian: Resistenza

TEXT.English: After you capture a [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City[\LINK], it may be a while before its citizens recognize their good fortune in having gained such a wise and benevolent leader as yourself. In the meantime, they may "resist" your rule. Further, cities under great cultural pressure may go into resistance before revolting and "flipping" to another civilization's control (see [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Borders[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Resistance[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]No Production, Commerce or Food:[\BOLD] If a city is in resistance, its population refuses to work. Thus the city produces no food, production, or commerce for the duration of the resistance. This may lead to [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]Starvation[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]No Cultural Radius:[\BOLD] The city has no [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Cultural Radius[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]No Defensive Bonus:[\BOLD] The city receives no defensive bonus for size or culture (see [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Cities[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duration of Resistance[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]The duration of a city's resistance is based upon its similarity or dissimilarity to your civilization. If you recapture one of your own cities shortly after it was taken from you, you'll see little or no resistance. A foreign city that has been under a lot of cultural pressure from your civilization will tend to spend less time in resistance, as will a city that shares your civilization's religion. A big, old foreign city with a lot of culture and a different religion will tend to resist longer.[PARAGRAPH:2]You cannot do much to shorten the duration of resistance once it is in progress. However you can lessen the chances of the city returning to resistance by passing your state religion to that city and building temples and such, and by raising the city's culture and reducing any outside cultural pressure on that city. It is also a good idea to have one or two units garrisoning a city in resistance.[PARAGRAPH:2]A [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great Artist[\LINK] can instantly end resistance in a city by creating a Great Work in it - but be warned that this will consume the Artist.
TEXT.French: Lorsque vous capturez une [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]ville[\LINK], il faut attendre quelques tours avant que la population ne réalise la chance qu'elle a d'avoir gagné un héros aussi dévoué et bon que vous. En attendant, elle risque de "résister" à l'envahisseur. De plus, les villes sous forte pression culturelle risquent de passer de la résistance à la révolte avant de rejoindre une autre civilisation (voir la section [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]frontières[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effets de la résistance[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ni production, ni commerce, ni nourriture:[\BOLD] une ville qui résiste refuse de travailler. Ainsi, elle ne produit ni nourriture, ni points de production ou de commerce tant que dure la résistance. Il y a donc un risque de [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]famine[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Pas de rayonnement culturel:[\BOLD] la ville n'a plus aucun [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]rayonnement culturel[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Pas de bonus défensif:[\BOLD] la ville n'a plus de bonus défensif lié à sa taille ou à sa culture (voir la section [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]villes[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Durée de la résistance[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]La durée de la résistance d'une ville dépend du niveau de sa ressemblance avec votre civilisation. Si vous reprenez une de vos villes peu après l'avoir perdue, il y aura peu voire pas de résistance. Une ville étrangère qui a été soumise à une forte pression culturelle de la part de votre civilisation restera moins longtemps en résistance, idem pour une ville partageant la même religion que vous. Mais une grande ville étrangère, ayant une forte culture et une religion différente de la vôtre, résistera plus longtemps.[PARAGRAPH:2]Il n'y a pas grand-chose à faire pour raccourcir la durée de la résistance, une fois qu'elle est lancée. Cependant, vous pouvez réduire le risque de reprise de la résistance en imposant votre religion par la construction de petits lieux de culte, en augmentant la culture de la ville et en réduisant la pression culturelle extérieure. Il est aussi utile de maintenir une ou deux unités en garnison dans une ville qui résiste.[PARAGRAPH:2]Un [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]artiste illustre[\LINK] peut mettre fin instantanément à la résistance en y créant une grande oeuvre (mais attention, l'artiste sera perdu).
TEXT.German: Haben Sie eine fremde [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Stadt[\LINK] erobert, widersetzt sich die Bevölkerung der Fremdherrschaft oft. Besonders in Städten mit großer Kultur können die Bewohner offen revoltieren. Weitere Informationen dazu finden Sie im Abschnitt [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Grenzen[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Auswirkungen des Widerstands[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Keine Produktion, keine Wirtschaft, keine Nahrung:[\BOLD] In einer Phase des Widerstands legt die Bevölkerung einer Stadt die Arbeit nieder. In dieser Zeit sinken die Nahrungs-, Produktions- und Wirtschaftserträge der Stadt auf 0. Dadurch droht wiederum die Gefahr einer [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]Hungersnot[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Kein Kulturradius:[\BOLD] Die Stadt hat keinen [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Kulturradius[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Kein Verteidigungsbonus:[\BOLD] Die Stadt erhält keinen Verteidigungsbonus für ihre Größe oder ihre Kultur. Weitere Informationen dazu finden Sie im Abschnitt [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Städte[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Dauer des Widerstands[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Die Dauer des Widerstands hängt von den Gemeinsamkeiten der eroberten Stadt mit Ihrer Zivilisation ab. Erobern Sie eine Ihrer eigenen Städte unmittelbar nach der Besetzung zurück, ist der Widerstand minimal. Fremde Städte, auf die Sie großen kulturellen Druck ausgeübt haben, geben ihren Widerstand in der Regel schon nach kurzer Zeit auf. Dies gilt auch für Städte, die den Glauben ihrer Zivilisation teilen. Eine große Kulturstadt mit einer eigenen Religion widersetzt sich einem Eroberer deutlich länger.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ihre Möglichkeiten, den Widerstand zu brechen, sind begrenzt. Sie können allerdings die Wahrscheinlichkeit, dass sich eine eroberte Stadt erneut widersetzt, senken, indem Sie Ihre Religion in der jeweiligen Stadt zur Staatsreligion erklären. Errichten Sie außerdem Tempel und andere religiöse Gebäude und fördern sie die Stadtkultur. Außerdem kann es nicht schaden, in einer rebellischen Stadt ein paar Soldaten zu stationieren.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ein [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Großer Künstler[\LINK] kann den Widerstand in einer Stadt durch die Schaffung eines Großen Kunstwerks sofort beenden, wobei der Künstler aber verbraucht wird.
TEXT.Italian: Dopo aver conquistato una [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]città[\LINK], può passare un po' di tempo prima che i cittadini comprendano quale immensa fortuna gli è toccata in sorte, finendo sotto la tua ala protettiva. Nel frattempo, possono opporre "resistenza" al tuo governo. Inoltre, città sotto grandi pressioni culturali possono attraversare un periodo di resistenza prima di ribellarsi e passare sotto il controllo di un'altra civiltà (vedi la voce [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]confini[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effetti della resistenza[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Niente produzione, commercio o cibo:[\BOLD] se una città sta facendo resistenza, la sua popolazione si rifiuta di lavorare, e di conseguenza la città non produce nulla per tutta la durata della resistenza. Questa situazione può portare alla [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]carestia[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Nessun raggio d'azione culturale:[\BOLD] La città non ha alcun [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]raggio d'azione culturale[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Nessun bonus difensivo:[\BOLD] la città non riceve alcun bonus difensivo per la sua dimensione o cultura (vedi [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]città[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Durata della resistenza[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]La durata della resistenza di una città si basa sulle analogie e le differenze con la tua civiltà. Se torni a catturare una tua città che ti era stata portata via poco tempo prima, incontrerai pochissima (se non nulla) resistenza. Una città straniera che è stata per molto tempo sotto la pressione culturale della tua città tenderà ad avere una resistenza di breve durata, così come le città che hanno la tua stessa religione. Una città straniera molto grande, ricca, stabilita da molto tempo, con una forte influenza culturale e una diversa religione resisterà per molto più tempo.[PARAGRAPH:2]Una volta iniziata, c'è ben poco che puoi fare per ridurre la durata della resistenza. Puoi tuttavia diminuire le probabilità che questa condizione di verifichi nuovamente, passandole la tua religione ufficiale, costruendo templi, aumentando il livello culturale della città e riducendo la pressione culturale che viene dall'esterno. È una buona idea avere anche un paio di unità che presidino la città durante la resistenza.[PARAGRAPH:2]Un [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Grande Artista[\LINK] può immediatamente porre fine alla resistenza di una città creando al suo interno una Grande Opera - ma ricorda che questo verrà sacrificato nel procedimento.
TEXT.Spanish: Después de que captures una [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]ciudad[\LINK], los ciudadanos pueden tardar un poco en comprender la suerte que han tenido de conseguir a un líder tan benevolente y sabio como tú. Mientras tanto, es posible que se "resistan" a que los gobiernes. Además, las ciudades que estén sometidas a una gran presión cultural puede que se resistan antes de rebelarse y "pasarse" al control de otra civilización (ver [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Fronteras[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Efectos de la resistencia[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]No hay producción, comercio ni alimentos:[\BOLD] Si una ciudad se resiste, su población se negará a trabajar. Así, la ciudad no generará alimentos, producción ni comercio mientras dure la resistencia. Esto puede llevar a una [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]hambruna[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]No hay radio cultural:[\BOLD] La ciudad carecerá de [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]radio cultural[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]No hay bonificación defensiva:[\BOLD] La ciudad no recibirá bonificaciones defensivas por su tamaño o cultura (ver [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Ciudades[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duración de la resistencia[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]La duración de la resistencia de una ciudad se basará en las similitudes o diferencias que tenga con tu civilización. Si recuperas una de tus propias ciudades poco después de que te la hayan arrebatado, encontrarás muy poca o ninguna resistencia. Normalmente, una ciudad extranjera que haya estado bajo mucha presión cultural de tu civilización se resistirá menos tiempo, al igual que una ciudad que comparta la religión de tu civilización. Asimismo, una ciudad grande y antigua, con mucha cultura y una religión distinta, se resistirá más.[PARAGRAPH:2]No puedes hacer gran cosa por acortar la duración de la resistencia una vez esté en marcha. No obstante, puedes reducir las posibilidades de que una ciudad pase a resistirse si le transmites tu religión oficial, templos y demás, aumentas su cultura y le reduces toda presión cultural foránea. También es buena idea tener un par de unidades que guarnezcan una ciudad que se resista.[PARAGRAPH:2]Un [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]gran artista[\LINK] puede poner fin de inmediato a la resistencia en una ciudad creando una gran obra, pero ten en cuenta que se consumirá en el proceso.

TEXT.English: The world of Civilization IV contain various "natural resources" that have benefits for the civilizations which possess them. Some provide military benefits - the "horse" resource allows the creation of mounted units such as the [LINK=UNIT_CHARIOT]Chariot[\LINK] early on and [LINK=UNIT_CAVALRY]Cavalry[\LINK] in the Renaissance period. Some provide productivity benefits - marble decreases the labor required to construct the [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Parthenon[\LINK] wonder, for example. Other resources provide health and happiness to your cities, allowing them to grow to larger sizes and increase in power. A civilization that possesses a variety of resources will have a distinct advantage over one that possesses few or no resources, and resources are one of the most important factors to keep in mind when choosing city sites with settlers.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Discovering Resources[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Some resources - rice, gold, etc. - begin the game visible. You will be able to see these resources as soon as their space is visible (see [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Exploration[\LINK]). Other resources are hidden at the start of play: they are not uncovered until you have acquired specific [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]Technologies[\LINK]. Copper is a good example of such a hidden resource; at game start no copper is visible anywhere on the map, but once you acquire the [LINK=TECH_BRONZE_WORKING]Bronze Working[\LINK] technology, copper is revealed.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Resource Locations[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Resources must be within your civilization's [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Cultural Borders[\LINK] in order to be connected to your [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]City Network[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Working Resources[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]In addition to resources' special abilities, they also usually provide some kind of food, commerce, or production bonus to their space. For example, a wheat resource adds a significant amount of food to the tile on which it is located. If a resource space is within a city radius, that city's laborers can work that space like any other - and they will almost certainly want to, since resources are usually highly desirable tiles.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Resources and Improvements[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Resources require that "improvements" be made to their spaces before you can access their special bonuses (see [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Improvements[\LINK] for more details). Improvements are constructed by [LINK=UNIT_WORKER]Workers[\LINK] (except for water resources, which are improved by [LINK=UNIT_WORKBOAT]Work Boats[\LINK]). If an improvement is pillaged or otherwise destroyed, you lose the resource's benefits until the improvement is reconstructed.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duplicate Resources[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]It is quite possible to have two or more of the same resource within your borders. Except for each space's production, commerce, and food value (see "Working Resources" above), you gain no additional benefit from multiple resources; a single resource is enough to take care of all of your civilization's needs. You may wish to hold onto the extras in case one is captured by an enemy, or you may want to trade the extras to other civilizations in exchange for their extra resources (see below).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Trading Resources[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You can trade any resource to other civilizations if that resource has been improved, and if it is connected by your [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]City Network[\LINK] to your capital city (see [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomacy[\LINK] for more details on trading).
TEXT.French: Le monde de Civilization IV contient différentes "ressources naturelles" dont profitent les civilisations qui en disposent. Certaines ont des avantages militaires: le cheval permet ainsi de créer des unités montées comme les [LINK=UNIT_CHARIOT]chars[\LINK] en début de partie, puis pendant la Renaissance, la [LINK=UNIT_CAVALRY]cavalerie[\LINK]. Certaines ressources ont des avantages en termes de production: le marbre, par exemple, réduit le travail nécessaire pour construire la merveille [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Parthénon[\LINK]. D'autres ressources améliorent la santé et le bonheur de vos villes, leur permettant ainsi de se développer davantage, et de gagner en puissance. Une civilisation qui dispose de nombreuses ressources est véritablement avantagée par rapport à une autre qui en a peu ou pas. Ainsi, les ressources sont un élément à prendre en compte quand vous cherchez un endroit pour construire une ville.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Découvrir des ressources[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Certaines ressources (riz, or, etc.) sont tout de suite visibles, dès la découverte de leur case (voir la section [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]exploration[\LINK]). D'autres ressources sont cachées en début de partie: vous devez découvrir les [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]technologies[\LINK] qui leur sont associées pour les voir. Ainsi, le bronze ne devient visible qu'une fois que vous avez découvert la technologie du [LINK=TECH_BRONZE_WORKING]travail du bronze[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Emplacement des ressources[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Les ressources doivent être à l'intérieur des [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]frontières culturelles[\LINK] de votre civilisation pour les relier à votre [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]réseau urbain[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Exploiter les ressources[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Outre leurs capacités spéciales, les ressources donnent à leur case un bonus de nourriture, de production ou de commerce. Une ressource de blé, par exemple, augmente de manière notable la nourriture disponible sur la case qu'elle occupe. Si une case ressource est située dans le rayon d'action d'une ville, les ouvriers peuvent l'exploiter comme n'importe quelle autre ressource, et ils le feront probablement, ces cases étant généralement très profitables.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ressources et améliorations[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Pour bénéficier des bonus des ressources, vous devez d'abord "améliorer" leur case (pour plus de détails, consultez la section [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]améliorations[\LINK]). Les améliorations sont réalisées par les [LINK=UNIT_WORKER]ouvriers[\LINK] (sauf les ressources maritimes, qui sont améliorées par les [LINK=UNIT_WORKBOAT]bateaux-ateliers[\LINK]). Lorsqu'une amélioration est pillée ou détruite, vous perdez le bénéfice de la ressource jusqu'à sa reconstruction.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ressources multiples[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Vous pouvez bien sûr posséder plusieurs fois la même ressource. Cependant, vous n'en tirerez aucun avantage supplémentaire, si ce n'est pour les villes qui les exploitent et qui obtiennent plus de nourriture, de commerce ou de production (voir plus haut: "Exploiter les ressources"). En fait, une seule ressource suffit pour alimenter toute votre civilisation. Vous pouvez néanmoins garder plusieurs fois la même ressource au cas où l'une d'entre elles serait prise par un ennemi, ou vous pouvez échanger les ressources supplémentaires avec d'autres civilisations pour obtenir d'autres types de ressources (voir plus bas).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Echanger des ressources[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Vous pouvez échanger une ressource avec les autres civilisations, si celle-ci a été améliorée, et si elle est reliée par votre [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]réseau urbain[\LINK] à votre capitale (pour plus de détails sur les échanges, consultez la section [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]diplomatie[\LINK]).
TEXT.German: Die Welt von Civilization IV enthält eine Vielzahl natürlicher Ressourcen, deren Ausbeutung das Überleben einer Zivilisation deutlich erleichtert. Die Ressource "Pferd" ermöglicht Ihnen beispielsweise den Bau berittener Einheiten, wie beispielsweise [LINK=UNIT_CHARIOT]Streitwagen[\LINK] und [LINK=UNIT_CAVALRY]Kavallerie[\LINK]. Die Ressource "Marmor" beschleunigt den Bau des [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Parthenons[\LINK]. Einige Ressourcen verbessern darüber hinaus die Gesundheit und Zufriedenheit der Bevölkerung. Eine Zivilisation mit verschiedenen Ressourcen ist einem Volk mit wenigen oder keinen Ressourcen klar überlegen. Vergewissern Sie sich also, dass im Umland einer neuen Stadt ausreichend Ressourcen vorhanden sind, bevor Sie diese gründen.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Entdeckung von Ressourcen[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Einige Ressourcen, wie Reis oder Gold, sind bereits am Anfang des Spiels verfügbar. Sie werden angezeigt, sobald Sie das entsprechende Geländefeld erkunden. Weitere Informationen dazu finden Sie im Abschnitt [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Erkundung[\LINK]). Andere Ressourcen werden erst sichtbar, wenn Sie bestimmte [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]Technologien[\LINK] erforscht haben, beispielsweise Bronze. Diese wird erst nach der Erforschung der Technologie [LINK=TECH_BRONZE_WORKING]Bronzeverarbeitung[\LINK] sichtbar.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Lage von Ressourcen[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Sie können lediglich Ressourcen innerhalb Ihrer [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Kulturgrenzen[\LINK] ausbeuten. Darüber hinaus müssen sie sich im [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Stadtgebiet[\LINK] einer Stadt befinden oder über ein [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]Verkehrsnetz[\LINK] an diese angebunden sein.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Nutzung von Ressourcen[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Geländefelder mit Ressourcen bewirken meist einen Nahrungs-, Produktions- oder Wirtschaftsbonus. Die Ressource "Weizen" ist beispielsweise mit einem beträchtlichen Nahrungsbonus verbunden. Befindet sich das Geländefeld einer Ressource innerhalb des Stadtgebiets, kann es von Arbeitstrupps wie jedes andere Geländefeld bearbeitet werden.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ressourcen und Landschaftsverbesserungen[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Möchten Sie eine Ressource ausbeuten, müssen Sie meist eine Landschaftsverbesserung darauf errichten. Weitere Informationen dazu finden Sie im Abschnitt [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Verbesserungen[\LINK]). Für den Bau von Verbesserungen sind Ihre [LINK=UNIT_WORKER]Arbeitstrupps[\LINK] verantwortlich. Lediglich Meeres-Geländefelder werden von [LINK=UNIT_WORKBOAT]Arbeitsschiffen[\LINK] verbessert. Wird eine Landschaftsverbesserung geplündert oder zerstört, verlieren Sie bis zu ihrem Wiederaufbau alle damit verbundenen Boni.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Überschüssige Ressourcen[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Sie können durchaus über mehrere identische Ressourcen verfügen. Abgesehen von den Produktions-, Wirtschafts- und Nahrungsboni für das jeweilige Geländefeld (siehe oben) bergen diese allerdings keine weiteren Vorteile. Sie können die überschüssigen Ressourcen natürlich behalten oder gegen Ressourcen anderer Zivilisationen eintauschen (siehe unten).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Tausch von Ressourcen[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Sie können alle über ein [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]Verkehrsnetz[\LINK] mit Ihrer Hauptstadt verbundenen Ressourcen handeln. Weitere Informationen dazu finden Sie im Abschnitt [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomatie[\LINK].
TEXT.Italian: Il mondo di Civilization IV contiene svariate "risorse naturali" che possono arrecare beneficio alle civiltà che le possiedono. Alcune forniscono benefici di tipo militare - la risorsa "cavallo" consente la produzione di unità a cavallo come la [LINK=UNIT_CHARIOT]biga[\LINK] prima e la [LINK=UNIT_CAVALRY]cavalleria[\LINK] dopo, nel Rinascimento. Alcune forniscono benefici in termini di produttività - ad esempio, il marmo diminuisce il lavoro richiesto per la produzione del [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Partenone[\LINK]. Altre risorse possono fornire salute e contentezza alle tue città, consentendo loro di aumentare di dimensione e di aumentare il proprio potere. Una civiltà che possiede numerose risorse avrà diversi vantaggi rispetto a una che ne possiede poche o nessuna. La presenza di risorse è uno dei fattori da prendere maggiormente in considerazione quando si deve decidere l'ubicazione di una città.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Scoprire le risorse[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Alcune risorse, come il riso e l'oro sono visibili fin da subito, e le potrai vedere non appena la casella in cui si trovano diventa visibile (vedi [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]esplorazione[\LINK]). Altre risorse sono nascoste all'inizio della partita, e non possono essere scoperte fino a quando non avrai acquisito specifiche [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]tecnologie[\LINK]. Il bronzo è un esempio di risorsa nascosta: all'inizio della partita non si trova bronzo da nessuna parte nella mappa; esso diventerà visibile non appena conoscerai la tecnologia [LINK=TECH_BRONZE_WORKING]Lavorazione del bronzo[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ubicazione delle risorse[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Le risorse devono trovarsi all'interno dei [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]confini culturali[\LINK] della tua civiltà per poter essere connesse alla [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]rete cittadina [\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Lavorazione delle risorse[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Oltre alle abilità speciali a esse collegate, le risorse possono anche fornire - nella casella in cui si trovano - bonus per quanto riguarda cibo, commercio o produzione. Ad esempio, la risorsa frumento aggiunge un notevole quantitativo di cibo alla casella in cui si trova. Se una risorsa si trova all'interno del raggio d'azione di una città, allora i lavoratori di quella città possono lavorare quella casella esattamente come tutte le altre - e quasi certamente lo faranno, dal momento che quelle delle risorse sono caselle sempre molto ambite.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Risorse e miglioramenti[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Alcune risorse richiedono la costruzione di alcuni "miglioramenti" nelle loro caselle prima di poter accedere ai loro bonus speciali (vedi [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]miglioramenti[\LINK] per maggiori dettagli). I miglioramenti vengono costruiti dai [LINK=UNIT_WORKER]lavoratori[\LINK] (ad eccezione delle risorse presenti in acqua, che vengono migliorate dalle [LINK=UNIT_WORKBOAT]chiatte[\LINK]). Se un miglioramento viene saccheggiato o distrutto, perdi tutti i benefici della risorsa fino a quando il miglioramento non sarà ricostruito.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duplicazione di risorse[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]È possibile avere due o più fonti della medesima risorsa all'interno dei propri confini; ad eccezione dell'aumento di produzione, commercio e cibo legato alla casella in cui si trova (vedi "Lavorazione delle risorse" poco sopra), non ottieni ulteriori benefici dall'avere più risorse dello stesso tipo: una singola risorsa è sufficiente per tutti i bisogni della tua civiltà. Puoi volerne tenere qualcuna di riserva nel caso una venga catturata da un nemico, o puoi volerla scambiare per qualcosa di cui non disponi (vedi sotto).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Scambio di risorse[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Puoi scambiare qualsiasi risorsa con le altre civiltà se quella risorsa è stata migliorata, e se è collegata tramite la [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]rete cittadina[\LINK] alla tua capitale (per maggiori dettagli sugli scambi commerciali vedi [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomazia[\LINK]).
TEXT.Spanish: El mundo de Civilization IV tiene varios "recursos naturales" que otorgan beneficios a las civilizaciones que los poseen. Algunos otorgan ventajas militares. El recurso del "caballo" permite crear unidades montadas, como el [LINK=UNIT_CHARIOT]carro[\LINK] al principio de la partida y la [LINK=UNIT_CAVALRY]caballería[\LINK] ya en el Renacimiento. Algunos favorecen la productividad: el mármol disminuye el trabajo necesario para construir la maravilla del [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Partenón[\LINK], por ejemplo. Otros recursos proporcionan salud y felicidad a las ciudades, lo que les permite crecer hasta los mayores tamaños y aumentar en poder. Una civilización que cuente con una gran variedad de recursos tendrá una ventaja indiscutible sobre otra que tenga pocos o ninguno. Por ello, los recursos son uno de los factores más importantes a tener en cuenta a la hora de escoger emplazamientos de ciudades para los colonos.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Descubrir recursos[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Algunos recursos (arroz, oro, etc.) están visibles desde el principio de la partida. Podrás localizarlos en cuanto la casilla en que se encuentren esté al alcance de tu vista (ver [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Exploración[\LINK]). Hay otros que se hallan escondidos al empezar la partida: no los descubrirás hasta que hayas conseguido unas [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]tecnologías[\LINK] concretas. El bronce es un buen ejemplo de los recursos ocultos: al empezar la partida no hay nada de bronce visible en el mapa, pero cuando consigas la tecnología de la [LINK=TECH_BRONZE_WORKING]forja del bronce[\LINK], se mostrará dicho recurso.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ubicación de los recursos[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Los recursos han de estar dentro de las [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]fronteras culturales[\LINK] de una civilización para poder estar conectados con su [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]red de ciudades[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Trabajar los recursos[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Además de las capacidades especiales de los recursos, éstos también suelen proporcionar a su casilla alimentos de alguna clase, comercio o una bonificación a la producción. Por ejemplo, el recurso del trigo añade una cantidad relevante de alimentos a la casilla en la que se encuentre. Si la casilla donde está un recurso se encuentra dentro del radio de una ciudad, sus trabajadores podrán explotarla como cualquier otra. Y casi seguro que querrán hacerlo, ya que los recursos acostumbran a ser casillas muy deseables.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Recursos y mejoras[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Los recursos requieren que se hagan "mejoras" en las casillas en que se encuentren para que puedas obtener las bonificaciones especiales que dan (ver [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Mejoras[\LINK] para obtener más detalles). Los [LINK=UNIT_WORKER]trabajadores[\LINK] son los que construyen las mejoras (excepto los recursos acuáticos, que se mejoran mediante los [LINK=UNIT_WORKBOAT]barcos faeneros[\LINK]). Si una mejora es saqueada o destruida de cualquier otra forma, perderás los beneficios que otorgue el recurso hasta que la reconstruyas.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Recursos duplicados[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Es perfectamente posible tener dos o más fuentes de un mismo recurso dentro de tus fronteras. A excepción de los valores de alimentos, comercio y producción de cada casilla (ver anteriormente "Trabajar los recursos"), no se obtiene ningún beneficio adicional por tener varias fuentes de un mismo recurso: uno solo basta para satisfacer todas las necesidades de tu civilización. Te puede interesar tener recursos adicionales por si alguno lo capturase el enemigo o quizá quieras intercambiar los que te sobren por los de otra civilización (ver a continuación).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Intercambio de recursos[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Puedes intercambiar cualquier recurso con otra civilización si dicho recurso ha sido mejorado y si está unido a tu capital mediante una [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]red de ciudades[\LINK] (ver [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomacia[\LINK] para obtener más detalles).

TEXT.English: by Jdog5000[PARAGRAPH:2]This component allows sections of disgruntled empires to rise up together and demand changes or attempt to break away from the motherland. No matter what the source of the complaint, you will be given an option to either ignore the complaint or accept the cities demands. If their demands go unmet and situations deteriorate, the cities may give you an ultimatum and take up arms if you do not comply![PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]How it works[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This component is intended to add realistic dynamics to the game, making keeping your cities and regions happy more important and challenging. Each city in your empire will have factors that make it want to stay and factors that make it want to rebel. If you cannot find a balance that keeps each of your cities happy, you will face revolts! Revolts come in many different styles, including requests to change civics, requests to change state religion, and demands for independence. No matter what the scenario, you will always be given choices when confronted with a rebellious city.[PARAGRAPH:2]This component has been updated to support Vassal states and other new features of Warlords. It also now incorporates most of the ideas from the prior Rebellion component. The AI logic appears bug free, but it's difficult to test all the human popup handling. However, it has undergone extensive testing and is in a good working state.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]More Details[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Each city has a Revolution Index, and when that index gets up towards 1000 they start to get restless. You will be warned whenever a city passes over 900 and about every 15 turns while it's in the danger zone, and once over 1000 it may instigate a revolution. Other nearby cities with rev indices over 600 can join in a revolution. If a city is unhappy, things are very similar but the minimum threshold for a revolution drops quickly with the number of unhappy citizens. There are several different Revolution styles and the situation in the Revolution instigating city determines the style. Many styles have peaceful and violent variants: denying a request will just agitate the city further, but denying a demand will lead to civil war! In order of precedence: [ICON_BULLET] [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Return to or reform dominant culture:[COLOR_REVERT] Cities in which you don't have a majority culture will become increasing aggitated and may attempt to break away for cultural reasons. The instigator and nearby, similarly cultured cities will ask (peaceful) or demand (violent) to join or reform a dead rival. Denying this request will cause your relations with the rival to deteriorate, and they may choose to declare war! [ICON_BULLET] [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Religious differences:[COLOR_REVERT] Cities may ask for a change away from Theocracy or to Freedom of Religion, or to switch your state religion. They can also ask or demand independence for religious reasons. [ICON_BULLET] [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Homeland revolutions:[COLOR_REVERT] Ask for various different civics. May ask for you to go on a crusade to capture your religion's holy city. [ICON_BULLET] [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Colonial revolutions:[COLOR_REVERT] Ask for change to representative government. (Independence handled below) [ICON_BULLET] [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Capital or majority of cities revolting:[COLOR_REVERT] Cities will ask for changes in away from repressive civics, or for some form of a say in the government. They can also ask or demand a change in ruler! If you're running a representative government, accepting their requests will mean facing election. If you are replaced, the game will automate some number of turns and then return control to you (this feature can be disabled). [ICON_BULLET] [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Independence:[COLOR_REVERT] If none of these particular conditions apply, the cities will ask for or demand independence. They may request full independence or assume Vassal status. [PARAGRAPH:2]If you face civil war, the situation may become quite dire. Strong garrisons may be able to maintain some semblance of control in some of the revolting cities, but weaker garrisons may be run out of town and the revolutionaries will take the city. Your homeland will not be the same for generations if you face multiple revolting cities on the battlefield! In addition, rebellious cities that the rebels have not yet taken may turn out rebel reinforcements.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]The Revolution Watch[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Clicking on the red fist button below the normal info buttons or pressing [BOLD]Ctrl-Shift-W[\BOLD] in the game will open the Revolution Watch popup. This popup displays which of your cities is in danger of rebelling, thinking about rebelling, or happy with your empire. In each category, the cities are ordered with the most rebellious towards the top. In addition, cities whose local situation is deterioirating are shown in orange. For specific information on how your civ-wide policies or the local city situation are effecting the rebelliousness of the city, scroll down and click the details button. This will open a new popup containing a lot of important information about the rebelliousness of your cities.[PARAGRAPH:2]At the top of this detail popup is an analysis of your national policies and situation. The effect of your civics, anarchy, golden age, empire size and fiscal situation are shown here. These affect all of your cities equally. Next is a city by city listing of local effects. The location of the city, the religions and cultures in the city, the happiness and healthiness of the people, the size of the city, the size of the city's garrison, and culture rate are all important factors you may see here. For both positive and negative effects the specific causes are ordered with the strongest first and grayscale indicating the intensity with whiter being more intense.[PARAGRAPH:2]Your civics can have a significant effect on how these local factors are felt. For example, running a theocracy will cause cities with non-state religions to be more rebellious, but keep cities with your state religion less rebellious. Representative government civics will greatly decrease the effects of distance on outlieing cities or colonies.

TEXT.English: A "revolution" occurs when you change your civilization's [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK] or [LINK=CONCEPT_RELIGION]Religion[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of a Revolution[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]During a revolution your civilization descends into one or more turns of "anarchy." A civilization in anarchy produces no food, commerce, or production! Any progress towards completing buildings, units, or projects is stopped until the revolution is over.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duration of a Revolution[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]The duration of a revolt depends upon the number of civics that you change: one or two civics will usually result in one turn of anarchy, while three or more civics may cause two or more turns of anarchy. The civics screen tells you how many turns of anarchy you may look forward to after you choose which civics to change. If the length of time is too long, either make fewer changes or cancel them altogether until you can spare the time. Religions always have one turn of revolution.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Immunity to Revolution[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Civilizations with [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]Leaders[\LINK] possessing the "Spiritual" trait do not suffer the effects of revolution or anarchy at all.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Delay Period[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]After a revolution has taken place, there is a short period of delay before another revolution can be carried out. When the "Revolution" button appears once again on the civics screen, your citizens have recovered enough from the previous anarchy to carry out another revolution.
TEXT.French: [H1]Révolution[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Une "révolution" se produit quand vous changez le [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]régime[\LINK] ou la [LINK=CONCEPT_RELIGION]religion[\LINK] de votre civilisation.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effets de la révolution[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Pendant une révolution, votre civilisation connaît un ou plusieurs tours "d'anarchie". Lorsque règne l'anarchie, il n'y a plus de récolte de nourriture, de commerce ni de production! Les constructions de bâtiments, d'unités et de projets sont arrêtées jusqu'à la fin de la révolution.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Durée d'une révolution[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]La durée de la révolution dépend du nombre de régimes que vous modifiez: changer un ou deux régimes provoque un tour de révolution, en changer trois ou plus entraînera au moins deux tours d'anarchie. L'écran des régimes politiques indique combien de tours d'anarchie vous subirez une fois que vous aurez sélectionné les régimes à changer. Si cela vous paraît trop long, vous pouvez limiter ou retarder les changements jusqu'à une période plus propice. Les religions provoquent systématiquement un tour de révolution.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Immunité à la révolution[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Les civilisations dont le [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]héros[\LINK] possède le trait de caractère "spirituel" ne subissent pas les effets de la révolution ou de l'anarchie.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Délai[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Après une révolution, aucune autre ne peut être initiée pendant un court délai. Lorsque le bouton "révolution" réapparaît sur l'écran des régimes, vos citoyens se sont remis de la période d'anarchie et peuvent à nouveau se révolter.
TEXT.German: Wechseln Sie die [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Gesellschaftsform[\LINK] oder die [LINK=CONCEPT_RELIGION]Staatsreligion[\LINK] Ihrer Zivilisation, kommt es zur Revolution.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Revolutionsfolgen[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Nach dem Wechsel der Gesellschaftsform versinkt Ihre Zivilisation einige Runden lang im Chaos. Während dieser Zeit produzieren ihre Bürger keine Nahrung mehr, bauen keine Ressourcen ab und stellen die Produktion ein.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Revolutionsdauer[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Die Dauer einer Revolution hängt von der Zahl der geänderten Gesellschaftsformen ab. Wechseln Sie eine oder zwei Gesellschaftsformen, dauern die Unruhen nur eine Runde. Wechseln Sie aber drei oder mehr Gesellschaftsformen, kann die Phase der Unruhen zwei oder mehr Runden umfassen. Im Gesellschaftsformen-Bildschirm wird die Dauer der Unruhen im Falle des Wechsels einer Gesellschaftsform angezeigt. Dauern Ihnen die Unruhen zu lange, sollten Sie weniger Gesellschaftsformen wechseln oder den Wechsel auf einen späteren Zeitpunkt verschieben. Ändern Sie die Staatsreligion, dauert die Revolution grundsätzlich eine Runde.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Immunität[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Zivilisationen mit spirituellen [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]Oberhäuptern[\LINK] haben beim Wechsel der Gesellschaftsform keine Revolution zu befürchten.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Verzögerungsphase[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Nach dem Wechsel der Gesellschaftsform müssen Sie einige Runden warten, bevor Sie die Gesellschaftsform erneut ändern können. Wird die Revolutionsschaltfläche im Gesellschaftsformen-Bildschirm wieder angezeigt, hat sich die Gesellschaft stabilisiert und ist bereit für die nächste Revolution.
TEXT.Italian: Una "rivoluzione" scoppia quando cambi la [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]forma di governo[\LINK] o la [LINK=CONCEPT_RELIGION]religione[\LINK] della tua civiltà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effetti di una rivoluzione[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Durante una rivoluzione, la tua civiltà attraversa uno o più turni di "anarchia". Una civiltà nell'anarchia non genera cibo, commercio, e neppure produzione! Qualunque avanzamento per la costruzione di edifici, unità e quant'altro è bloccato fino al termine della rivoluzione.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Durata di una rivoluzione[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]La durata di una rivoluzione dipende dal numero di forme di governo che decidi di cambiare: una o due portano solitamente a un turno di anarchia, tre o più possono portare a due o più turni di anarchia. La schermata della politica ti dice quanti turni di anarchia ti aspettano dopo che avrai scelto quali forme cambiare. Se la durata dell'anarchia è eccessiva, puoi ridurre il numero di cambiamenti o annullarli del tutto fino a quando non sarai nelle condizioni di risparmiare tempo. I cambiamenti che riguardano le religioni hanno sempre almeno un turno di rivoluzione.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Evitare la rivoluzione[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Le civiltà con [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]leader[\LINK] che possiedono il tratto "Spirituale" non subiscono gli effetti dell'anarchia o della rivoluzione.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Periodo di transizione[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Dopo che si è consumata una rivoluzione, c'è un breve periodo di tempo durante il quale non possono verificarsi altre rivoluzioni. Quando il pulsante "Rivoluzione" torna a essere visualizzato nella schermata della politica, vuol dire che i tuoi cittadini si sono ripresi a sufficienza dall'ultimo periodo di anarchia per poter affrontare una nuova rivoluzione.
TEXT.Spanish: Se da una "revolución" cuando cambian los [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]principios[\LINK] o la [LINK=CONCEPT_RELIGION]religión[\LINK] de tu civilización.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Efectos de la revolución[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Durante una revolución, la civilización cae en uno o más turnos de "anarquía". Una civilización sumida en la anarquía no genera alimentos, comercio ni producción. Cualquier avance destinado a completar edificios, unidades o proyectos quedará parado hasta que termine ese proceso.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duración de la revolución[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]La duración de la rebelión depende de la cantidad de principios que hayan cambiado: uno o dos suelen comportar un turno de anarquía, mientras que tres o más pueden hacer que se prolongue hasta tres o más turnos. La pantalla de principios indica cuántos turnos de anarquía puedes esperar después de que optes por cambiar los principios. Si ésta fuera a durar demasiado, sería mejor hacer menos cambios o cancelarlos todos hasta que te puedas permitir prescindir de ese tiempo. El cambio de religión siempre comporta un turno de revolución.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Inmunidad a la revolución[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Las civilizaciones con [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]líderes[\LINK] que tengan el rasgo de "espiritual" no sufren ningún efecto de la revolución ni de la anarquía.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Periodo de transición[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Después de que haya tenido lugar una revolución, hay un breve periodo de transición antes de que pueda llevarse a cabo otra. Cuando vuelva a aparecer el botón "Revolución" en la pantalla de principios, significa que los ciudadanos se han recobrado lo bastante de la anterior situación anárquica como para llevar a cabo otra revolución.

TEXT.English: In this mod, barbarian cities, if left to their own devices, will eventually settle down into full blown civs![PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]How it works:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Barbarian cities will settle down probabilistically, with several factor determining the odds. Starting with version 2.0, barb cities first become single city minor civs. These city states can't conduct diplomacy, so they're at war with everyone. When the new civ accomplishes something notable, a leader emerges and the civ settles down into a full civ. These accomplishments can include conquest, reaching a high population, reaching a high level of culture, building wonders, etc.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]More details:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The decision to have a barbarian city form a minor civ is based on the population and culture of the city, whether there are nearby civs, and whether the city was captured. When a minor civ forms, they take control of this single city and are given some units and techs to get started. Since they are a minor civ they're at war with everyone else and cannot conduct diplomacy, so you won't see them on the scoreboard.[PARAGRAPH:2]Each turn the minor civs are checked to see if they deserve to be upgraded to full civ status. When settling down into a full civ, these minor civs will take on one of two types: militaristic and builder. If they have conquered a city, they will immediately settle into a full, militaristic civ and continue the war against whomever they took a city from. If they have reached a high level of culture or built a wonder, they will settle as builders. If they settle due to high population or founding a religion, they have a probabilistic chance of being one or the other.[PARAGRAPH:2]The civs get several bonuses depending on whether they're militaristic or builder. Both types get a base set of defensive units and workers, plus some free techs known to a majority of the world. The new civ also gets a great person (to symbolize the leader who organized the horde), with the GP type depending on the type of consolidation. Their capital is given walls and a granary. If the cities have some culture, the new civ gets half of the total. These general effects for both types of rise of the barbs are intended to partly catch them up with the rest of the world.[PARAGRAPH:2]Militaristic consolidation is the most exciting in my view. It's intended to mimic the effect of Ghengis Khan or the Vikings. There are four different flavors of militaristic settling, Viking, Chariot, Horse, and balanced. Vikings get boats and mostly melee units, Chariot style is for earlier barb settling and they get chariots and some axes, Horse style is mostly Horse archers or Knights if late enough, while balanced gets an assortment of units. The strength of the military is fairly random, and increases as the eras go by. Odds of a militaristic build up increase if the new leader is Aggressive or Expansionist. Militaristic new civs will be behind in economic or social technology. They also get free barracks. Militaristic barbs have a good chance of getting a Great General when spawned.[PARAGRAPH:2]Builder consolidation is intended to mimic the rise of a new civ that isn't particularly militaristic. This type of civ gets additional techs, one or two of which they may be the first to research. They are given a Great Person and may build a wonder or discover a new tech. It's not uncommon for them to found a new religion. They are also given a bunch of extra infrastructure: extra worker, free settler, and some buildings like libraries, lighthouses, and forges (if they have the tech).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Notes on use:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]To make this component more exciting, the amount of Barbarian activity has generally been increased. Particularly, barbarian cities will form both earlier and more often to help this component fill in empty space in the game map with new players. With this change, a full standard map game will probably see a handful of barb civs emerge.[PARAGRAPH:2]One fun one to play is start a large world with only a handful of civs, then let the barbarians fill in the gaps. Be prepared for a potential invasion from a rising power! BarbarianCiv also works quite well with the Revolution component that can spawn barbarian rebels.[PARAGRAPH:2]On Terra maps, the new world will probably not be as empty as before. A new config variable, NewWorldPolicy, can be used to define how barb cities on their own continent behave so that you can customize how the new world will appear when the first explorers land. Options range from having it mostly full of civs to keeping barb cities as barbarian until someone starts colonizing.[PARAGRAPH:2]There are many other settings in the Revolution.ini config file, including MilitaryStrength which can be used to create massive military invasions and modifiers for controlling the odds of civ formation.
TEXT.French: Dans ce mod, les Villes barbares, lorsqu'elles sont laissées à leur sort, vont s'établir et devenir des civilisations, tout d'abord mineures (en guerre automatiquement et ne pouvant conduire de diplomatie), puis en vraies civilisations, en nouveau challenger[PARAGRAPH:2]Pour palier au retard de son apparition, la civilisation recevra des bonus, des technologies gratuires, et un nombre important d'unités militaires afin de pouvoir se défendre, voire capturer quelques villes voisines si le trait de charactère correspond.

TEXT.French: Civ Barbares

TEXT.English: This component renames civs based on their civics choices and other status factors. A civs names will change many times over the course of a game. While it has no actual effect on gameplay, it adds dynamic variety to the game.[PARAGRAPH:2]When a civ is created or changes their civics, they are potentially assigned a new name based on many factors. Civs spawned by either Revolution or BarbarianCiv will get temporary names indicating their status, like Mongolian Horde or Russian Rebels, until they're more firmly established. When a civ switches to Hereditary Rule their name will change to something like Kingdom of America, while under Representation or Universal Suffrage they would be the American Republic. Civs with only one city in the later stages of the game may have the city name included in their title, but their civ type will always be clarified as in the French KingDom of Paris. Vassals will also get different names. There are many different potential names, and even variations for civs with the same status to provide some flavor.[PARAGRAPH:2]All of the civics determinations are made using the added Revolution flags in the civics xml file to support variations on the standard civics systems. Having a civic with the isCommunism bool set will cause Communist style names. In addition, some civs have special names like show up in certain circumstances, like the German Reich and Arabian Caliphate. These determinations are made by matching text in the civs adjective (ie German or Arabian).[PARAGRAPH:2]This component has several features designed to support names of civs created by BarbarianCiv and Revolution, but would provide plenty of fun flavor name changes as a standalone mod or addition for other mods. It requires changes to the DLL to allow name changes to stick, but all name changes are generated in Python.
TEXT.French: Renomme les Noms des nations en fonction des Doctrines et du type de gouvernement. N'a aucun effet sur le Gameplay mais ajoute de la variété[PARAGRAPH:2]Lorsque la Civ est créé ou change de doctrines, un nouveau nom est créé. NDT - Attention, cette option comporte certaines incompatibilité avec la version française, et entraîne des fautes d'accords dans l'utilisation de adjectifs des civilisations (dans les évènements par exemple), et les accents ont du être supprimés.
TEXT.Russian: [H1]Динамические названия цивилизаций[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Цель:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Этот компонент переименовывает цивилизации, основанные на их гражданском выборе и других факторах статуса. Имена цивилизаций будут меняться много раз ход игры. Хотя он не оказывает реального влияния на игровой процесс, он добавляет динамическое разнообразие в игру.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Как это работает:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Когда цивилизация создается или изменяет свои парадигмы, они потенциально влияют на новое имя, основанное на многих факторах. Цивилизации, порожденные либо Revolution, либо BarbarianCiv, получат временные имена, указывающие на их статус, такие как монгольская орда или русские повстанцы, пока они не станут более прочными. Когда цивилизация переключается на наследственное правило, их имя меняется на что-то вроде Королевства Америки, в то время как под представительством или всеобщим голосованием они будут американской республикой. Цивилизации только с одним городом на более поздних этапах игры может быть название города, включенное в их название, но их тип цивилизации будет всегда уточняйте как во французском королевстве Париж. Вассалы также получат разные имена. Есть много разных потенциальных имен, и даже вариации для цивилизаций с одинаковым статусом, чтобы придать некоторую изюминку.[PARAGRAPH:2]Все определения парадигм сделаны с использованием добавленных флагов Revolution в файле "civics.xml" для поддержки вариации стандартных систем гражданственности. Так, принятие части или всех парадигм, имеющих отношение к коммунистическому строю, в итоге повлияет на конечное название державы (вместо Германии - ГДР, вместо России - Советский Союз, вместо - США - ССША и т.д.). Кроме того, некоторые цивилизации имеют специальные имена, например, появляются в определенных обстоятельствах, например, Германский рейх и Арабский халифат. Эти определения сделаны путем сопоставления текста в прилагательном civs (т. е. немецкий или арабский).[PARAGRAPH:2]Этот компонент имеет несколько функций, предназначенных для поддержки имен Цивилизации, созданные BarbarianCiv и Revolution, но обеспечили бы массу забавных изменений на уникальные имена в некоторых модах или дополнениях для других модов. Это требует изменений в DLL, чтобы позволить изменениям имени придерживаться, но все изменения имени генерируются в Python.

TEXT.French: Titre de Civ Dynamique

TEXT.English: With this component, civs who fall behind in tech but have lots of friends will receive some free research.[PARAGRAPH:2]When a civ falls behind by several techs, they qualify for tech "welfare." Each turn that they are significantly behind, they will receive some free beakers towards techs they can research. The amount of free beakers depends on how many civs they know who already have the tech and what there relationships are, although the rate for powerful military techs is lowered since civs try harder to keep them secret. If a civ is behind by a handful of techs, they will get fractions of a percent of the research per turn. If they are behind by a dozen or more, the rate increases.[PARAGRAPH:2]The diffusion of tech is capped so that civs don't receive techs for free but have to do the final research push themselves. The cap is low in the early eras, and moves up as the eras go on. If a civ is very far behind, the cap is ignored to try and keep them somewhat in the game.
TEXT.French: Avec ce composant, les Civs en retard au niveau technologique, mais avec des relations diplomatiques amicales, pourront rattraper leur retard.[PARAGRAPH:2]Une fois la civ considéré en retard technologiquement, elle obtient à chaque tour des points de recherche sur des technologies que ses relations diplomatiques ont déjà découvertes, rendant ainsi leur recherche plus rapide.
TEXT.Russian: [H1]Распространение технологий[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Содержание:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]С данной активной настройкой цивилизации, которые сильно отстают в технологиях, но имеют много друзей, получат некоторые бесплатные очки исследования.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Как работает эта опция:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Если некая цивилизация начинает заметно отставать от нескольких лидеров технологического развития, она получает шанс на научный прорыв. Всякий раз, когда такие страны значительно отстают, они получают бесплатные колбы для исследования всех доступных технологий. Количество бесплатных колбочек зависит от количества цивилизаций, с которыми они успели на этот момент установить контакт, от изученных ими технологий, и состояния их отношения. При этом шанс на получение солидных военных технологий снижен, поскольку цивилизации стараются хранить их в секрете. Если цивилизация отстает от горстки научных лидеров, они получат халявные доли процента исследования за ход. Если они отстают на дюжину или больше, то скорость еще больше возрастает.[PARAGRAPH:2]У распространения технологий есть ограничения, так что цивилизации не получают их бесплатно, а вынуждены сами делать последние, решающие исследования. Потолок дармовых колбочек и наук сравнительно низок в ранние эпохи и движется вверх по мере продолжения игровых эпох. Если наиболее передовая цивилизация-конкурент вырвалась далеко вперед, а страна-аутсайдер продолжает безнадежно отставать, в этом случае лимит временно отключается для того, чтобы удержать на плаву отсталые цивилизации.

TEXT.English: by eotinb, Ruff_Hi[PARAGRAPH:2]This is a mod to facilitate note taking, with Succession Games in mind.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Autolog can be configured in the Logging tab of the BUG Options Screen ([COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Alt+Ctrl+O[COLOR_REVERT]). To enable Autolog, you simply have to select the 'Enable Logging' checkbox. You can choose a customized name and path for your log file, or use the default one ('...\My Docs\My Games\Beyond the Sword\Autolog\playername.txt').[PARAGRAPH:2]You can also change the format used. The options are HTML, Plain Text, Forum Codes, and Forum Codes with color. Default is Forum Codes, which is designed to be copy and pasted straight to a forum such as CFC.[PARAGRAPH:2]The shortcut commands you should know for the Autolog are: [ICON_BULLET] [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Alt + L[COLOR_REVERT] - Toggle autologging. [ICON_BULLET] [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Alt + B[COLOR_REVERT] - Create Battle dump. [ICON_BULLET] [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Alt + E[COLOR_REVERT] - Add custom entry to Autolog.[PARAGRAPH:2]By default Autolog is disabled in this modpack.

[[BOLD]New User Interface Features[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Holding down SHIFT+ALT and clicking on a leader in the scoreboard toggles your civ's warplan between WARPLAN_PREPARING_TOTAL and NO_WARPLAN. This feature can be used to signal to your vassals that they should begin preparing for war with a particular player as well, allowing them to be much better prepared when you declare. Any warning you can give your vassals will help, but enough time to build one to two units in a city is best. WARNING: Use of this feature is not multiplayer compatible, WARPLANs are not sent across the network since they're otherwise only used by the AI and so it will lead to OOS errors if you have vassals.[PARAGRAPH:2]The scoreboard will show WAR in yellow instead of red when you have declared you are planning a war using the above feature.[PARAGRAPH:2]Added line to contact help text explaining that SHIFT+ALT clicking toggles war preparation plans.[PARAGRAPH:2]Air units can now be set to explore, they use the same explore logic as AI planes and then have additional logic if that doesn't push a mission. Note that planes on auto explore always move at the very beginning of your turn!
